clinical_study.brief_title: Succinylcholine or Rocuronium for Rigid Bronchoscopy Under General Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Interventional Rigid Bronchoscopy Under General Anesthesia: Influence of the Muscle Relaxant, Succinylcholine or Rocuronium, on the Quality of the Surgical Procedure

brief_summary.textblock: Myorelaxation is generally used as a part of general anesthesia for interventional rigid bronchoscopy. Succinylcholine is most often used because its short duration of action but rocuronium can be used since sugammadex permits a rapid and complete reversal of the neuromuscular block. The aim of ths study is to compare both agents.

clinical_study.why_stopped: recent publication (Ghezel-Ahmadi. Thorac Cardiovasc Surg. 2014 Nov 21)

primary_outcome.measure: Score of quality of the surgical procedure
primary_outcome.description: The quality of the surgical procedure is evaluated by the surgeon (composite score) who is unaware of the neuromuscular agent used (see Fuchs-Buder et al. Acta Anaesthesiol Scand 2007;51(7):789-808)

secondary_outcome.description: The quality of anesthesia is evaluated by the anesthesist in charge on a scale 0-30 (0-10 for the induction ; 0-10 for maintenance; 0-10 for recovery)

arm_group.description: Succinylcholine 1 mg/kg and a second dose if necessary.
rocuronium 0,9 mg/kg with additional boluses of 0,3 mg/kg f necessary

intervention.description: Succinylcholine 1 mg/kg and a second dose if necessary. Rocuronium 0,4 mg/kg can be used as a rescue
rocuronium 0,9 mg/kg with additional boluses of 0,3 mg/kg f necessary

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients scheduled for an interventional rigid bronchoscopy under general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnant woman or woman of childbearing age,
- morbid obesity,
- drug allergy,contra-indication to succinylcholine, rocuronium, sugammadex, propofol, remifentanil,
- history of central neurological or brain damage,
- psychotropic treatment,
- pacemaker,
- renal failure,
- disease of the neuromuscular junction.
